Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Integrated Investigations of Isotope Fractionation in Magmatic Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Significant variations in stable isotope ratios of several non-traditional stable isotope (NTSI) systems have recently been observed in igneous rocks. The origin of these variations remains largely unknown despite the critical observation that the variations correlate with extent of differentiation. At present, it is not possible to evaluate whether traditional processes such as fractional crystallization may account for the observations, because the fractionation factors among magmatic phases have not been determined. The exciting new discovery that large isotopic fractionations occur in melts held within a temperature gradient offers an alternative possible explanation for the observed isotopic variations, but to fully assess this mechanism requires further experimental investigation. The fractionation by thermal diffusion appears to be so large that it may provide the basis for a unique tool to discern the role of thermal-gradient-driven processes for magmatic differentiation. This project represents a synergistic collaboration involving four interrelated and complementary studies: 1) Characterize NTSI fractionation in laboratory silicate Soret (fully molten) experiments. Soret experiments will use both natural compositions and selected simple systems; 2) Characterize major and trace element behavior and NTSI fractionation in thermal migration (partially molten) experiments; these will focus on basalt to rhyolite bulk compositions and also determine thermal diffusion fractionations for Mg, Si and Fe; 3) Use molecular dynamics simulations of isotope fractionation within a temperature gradient in the MgO-SiO2 system to investigate the physical basis for the effects of thermal diffusion on NTSI fractionation; 4) Determine equilibrium fractionation factors between melts, vapor and mineral phases for Mg, Si and Fe using the three-isotope method. The proposed science plan brings together four groups of researchers with complementary expertise. The team connects diverse areas of petrology/geochemistry research from field petrology to experimental petrology to molecular dynamics simulation. The project will provide constraints on a first-order problem in igneous petrology, the origin of NTSI fractionations in igneous rocks. It will provide further understanding of the fundamental process of thermal diffusion and its strong mass dependence and improve the NTSI tool for discerning the role of temperature gradients in magma differentiation.

Broader Impacts: The project will support involvement of three graduate students, a postdoc and early career faculty (UNLV) and a research scientist (UCD) in a complex project utilizing a broad range of conceptual, analytical, experimental and simulation tools. Group meetings and video conferencing will foster the collaboration and involve the students and postdoc in all aspects of the study. Each PI expects to incorporate the results of this study into regular teaching of petrology, geochemistry and numerical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Isotopes are important tracers of physical and chemical processes in volcanic systems, as well as in many other branches of Earth sciences, biology, and medicine. Accurate interpretation of isotope variations found in volcanic materials depends on knowledge of the physical processes by which the isotopes are separated. Isotope variations in lavas have recently been discovered for a wide range of "heavy" elements that had not previously been considered because isotope fractionation was assumed to be negligible for these elements. These variations can potentially be used as powerful tools to understand processes in the deep magmatic systems that underlie volcanoes, prior to eruptive events, but to interpret them it is necessary to know the mechanism(s) by which they are fractionated.

Isotopes may be fractionated (1) by a temperature gradient, (2) by chemical concentration gradients, or (3) by equilibrium fractionation between minerals and magmas (i.e. minerals that crystallize out of the magma may have a different isotope mix than the magmas they leave behind, due to quantum mechanical zero-point energy effects). Our study focused primarily on the first two possibilities, but we also initiated experiments to address the third.

We performed molecular dynamics simulations of simple magmatic systems held within a temperature gradient, and found that heavy isotopes always segregated to the cold region, in agreement with all experiments we know of, both on magmas and other materials (including gases). Furthermore, the magnitude of the effect we found in the simulations was in agreement with experiments on more complicated magmas. All of the results are consistent with isotope fractionation by classical mechanical effects, having to do with momentum transfer as atoms and molecules collide with each other. This is important because it had been suggested that these effects may instead be due to quantum mechanical effects, in which case the magnitude of the fractionation is much more difficult to predict, and has to be done on a case-by-case basis even to predict the approximate magnitude. We instead showed that the approximate magnitude of the effect can be predicted simply according to the classical theory, which makes it very easy to place bounds on the effect.

Secondly, we performed molecular dynamics simulations to determine how the mobility of an isotope depends on its mass. When magmas of different composition mix, isotopes can be separated because light isotopes are more mobile than their heavier counterparts. The question is, by how much? Over the last decade there have been a few experimental studies that addressed this question, but no theoretical work. We developed molecular dynamics simulations to address this issue for a simple magma analog composition (MgSiO3). Our results for the mass dependence of magnesium diffusion are in agreement with experimental findings, and we obtained the first estimates for the mass dependence of silicon diffusion (silicon is an essential component of all magmas), which is much less than for magnesium. The likely explanation for this behavior is that silicon is part of a strong network of atoms that has to move cooperatively in order for silicon to diffuse. These cooperative motions dilute the effect of changing the mass of the silicon atom - in effect they raise the total mass of the unit that is moving, and reduce the effect of changing the mass of the silcon atom. Magnesium, on the other hand, is not tightly bound to the silicate network and is more free to move on its own. Changing the mass of magnesium therefore has a bigger effect. Based on our results we were able to make quantitative predictions of the degree of isotope fractionation that would be expected when magmas mix.
